byline.contributor: Michael M. Grynbaum and Rick Rojas contributed reporting.

abstract: Divisive battle between New York City Police Commissioner William J Bratton and predecessor Raymond W Kelly highlights obscurities in how city compiles crime statistics, and powerful implications methods can have; department is moving vigorously to push back against Kelly's assertion that it manipulated statistics in order to give false impression of safer city following implementation of more liberal policing tactics.
lead_paragraph: Commissioner William J. Bratton and his predecessor, Raymond W. Kelly, are sparring over the veracity of the city’s crime statistics.

headline.main: Police Leaders’ Competing Claims Draw Focus to How New York Counts Crimes
headline.print_headline: Shedding Light on How a City Counts Crimes

snippet: Commissioner William J. Bratton and his predecessor, Raymond W. Kelly, are sparring over the veracity of the city’s crime statistics.
